hotspots.label: Tire Tread Pattern
hotspots.fact: The deep grooves and bumps on this tire are called tread, and they help the tire grip the road better. This is a good example of how the shape and texture of an object affects how it moves and stops. A tire with worn-down tread doesn't grip as well, so the car takes longer to stop when the brakes are applied.

vocabulary.definition: A force that happens when two surfaces rub together and slows down or stops movement. The tire tread creates more friction with the road.

hotspots.label: Metal Wheel Rim
hotspots.fact: The metal wheel rim is a rigid material that holds the tire in place and helps support the weight of the car. Metal is strong and doesn't bend easily, which makes it perfect for this job. This shows how we choose different materials based on the properties we need for a design.

vocabulary.definition: The special qualities of something that make it good or bad for different jobs, like being hard, flexible, heavy, or light.

hotspots.label: Worn Tread Surface
hotspots.fact: You can see the tire tread is dirty and worn from rolling on the ground and experiencing friction. As tires wear down over time, they lose their grip on the road because there's less surface area to create friction. This is why car tires need to be replaced eventually to keep cars safe.

vocabulary.definition: When something gets damaged or worn out from being used over time, like how a tire gets smoother the more you drive on it.

hotspots.label: Tire Rubber Compound
hotspots.fact: Tires are made of rubber, which is a material chosen because it is flexible and has good friction with the road. The rubber can grip and hold onto the road surface, which helps the car stop when needed. Engineers designed tires this way to help control motion and keep cars safe.

vocabulary.definition: A push or pull that can make something move, stop moving, or change direction. Friction between the tire and road creates a force that slows down the car.
